channel.title: Simple Ruby task
channel.description:
I found this great website that has many assignments and projects for various languages, so I decide to take a look at Ruby. The current assignment I'm on requires that I create an array of add numbers and iterate through them and print out double their original values. Here is the current code block: [code=ruby] odds = [1,3,5,7,9]
odds.each do |x| # Code input here print #{x} end [/code] The comment is where I'm suppose to have a logical operator that doubles each member of the array. I understand how to add each member (x += 1), but I'm not quite sure how to double. I've tried almost everything and I've had no luck. I'm not sure if a part of the code is wrong, or if I'm not using the proper logical operator. Any help?

item.title: Simple Ruby task
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

I’m pretty new at Python, how does the “x for x” work?

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Ruby task
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“ziplock, post:12, topic:478119”]Ruby is so weird.

[code=python]
odds = range(1, 11)

for num in odds:
if num & 1 != 0:
print num * 2
[/code][/quote]

You can use xrange() instead of range() if you don’t need the actual list (it’s slightly faster in most circumstances, especially when generating a large list/iterator).

also:

[code=python]odds = [x for x in xrange(1, 10) if x & 1 != 0]

This also works (albeit slightly slower):

odds = filter(lambda x: x & 1 != 0, xrange(1, 10))

print odds
print map(lambda x: x * 2, odds)[/code]

huehuehue

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Ruby task
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

[quote=“Whackatre, post:8, topic:478119”]Sure you could iterate through the array with a block, but why not use functional programming to modify each member of your array instead? I find the Array#map method very useful and very cool.

I would probably do this:

[code=ruby]# The “odds”.
odds = (1…10).select { |x| x % 2 != 0 }
p odds

Print a new array consisting of each number in

the aforementioned array, except doubled.

p odds.map { |x| x * 2 }[/code]

Output:

[quote][1, 3, 5, 7, 9]
[2, 6, 10, 14, 18][/quote]

Otherwise if you want a block you could possibly do it like this:

odds.each do |x| print "#{x * 2}, " end[/quote]
Thanks, but the assignment only allows me to program with a skeleton it has set up. It does not detect the code block as being correct if it is done a different way, regardless if the other way is correct or not.

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Ruby task
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

Sure you could iterate through the array with a block, but why not use functional programming to modify each member of your array instead? I find the Array#map method very useful and very cool.

I would probably do this:

[code=ruby]# The “odds”.
odds = (1…10).select { |x| x % 2 != 0 }
p odds

Print a new array consisting of each number in

the aforementioned array, except doubled.

p odds.map { |x| x * 2 }[/code]

Output:

[1, 3, 5, 7, 9] [2, 6, 10, 14, 18]

Otherwise if you want a block you could possibly do it like this:

odds.each do |x| print "#{x * 2}, " end

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Ruby task
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

I found this great website that has many assignments and projects for various languages, so I decide to take a look at Ruby. The current assignment I’m on requires that I create an array of add numbers and iterate through them and print out double their original values. Here is the current code block:

odds = [1,3,5,7,9]

odds.each do |x|
	# Code input here 
	print #{x}
	end

The comment is where I’m suppose to have a logical operator that doubles each member of the array. I understand how to add each member (x += 1), but I’m not quite sure how to double. I’ve tried almost everything and I’ve had no luck. I’m not sure if a part of the code is wrong, or if I’m not using the proper logical operator. Any help?

Read full topic
